newsitem.title: USA: Senate approves three judges, more nominees await.
newsitem.headline: Senate approves three judges, more nominees await.

text.p: The Senate on Friday approved the long-delayed appointment of three federal judges, even as Democrats charged Republicans were continuing to block a host of other White House judicial nominees.
"It's zero population growth in the federal judiciary," said Vermont Democratic Sen. Patrick Leahy, complaining that the Senate had approved just five judges this year, including Friday's action.
Democrats have said majority Republicans were purposely slowing the process to prevent "activist" candidates from sitting on the federal bench.
Republicans denied they were out to get President Clinton's nominees.
They said the 100 vacancies on the federal bench were due in part to a record number of retirements. They also griped that the White House had not sent up nominees to fill most of the empty slots.
"Federal judges should not be confirmed as part of a numbers game or to reduce a vacancy rate," said Judiciary Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch, a Utah Republican.
"The record of activism demonstrated by so many of the Clinton judges and nominess shows (the need for) more vigilance," he said.

By voice vote the Senate approved the nominations of Donald Middlebrooks as U.S. district judge for the Southern District of Florida; Jeffrey Miller as U.S. district judge for the Southern District of California and Robert Pratt as U.S. district judge for the Southern District of Iowa.
The large number of vacancies gave Clinton the opportunity to reshape the federal court system, which has a high number of Republican appointees.
In response, conservative groups organised to challenge what they termed a trend toward activist appointments by the White House.
Senate Republicans last month rejected proposals that would have given individual senators more authority to halt nominations.
Republicans did approve a policy statement that the Senate should turn away judicial nominees that were considered to have activist philosophies.
